JUDGES: András Baka;Elisabet Fura;Ireneu Cabral Barreto;Jean-Paul Costa;Mindia Ugrekhelidze
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE , GPE .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant brought a civil action against a private person . On DATE ORG allowed his claim and ordered the debtor to pay him arrears in the amount of MONEY ( MONEY ( ORG ) ) plus CARDINAL NORP laris ( ( GEL ) – EUR CARDINAL ) for the costs and expenses associated with the court proceedings . The judgment was never appealed against and became binding .
CARDINAL . NORP Since the debtor refused to abide by the judgment , the applicant applied to ORG of GPE ( “ the LAW ” ) , requesting the initiation of enforcement proceedings .

CARDINAL . In a letter of DATE , ORG informed the applicant that , pursuant to section CARDINAL of LAW , he was to bear the “ preliminary expenses associated with enforcement measures ” . The letter , however , did not specify which measures were envisaged and what their costs were .

CARDINAL . Being in receipt of only a DATE pension of GEL DATE ( EUR CARDINAL ) at the material time , the applicant was unable to pay for the initiation of enforcement proceedings . He appealed instead to ORG and ORG of the ORG , requesting the initiation of criminal proceedings against the debtor ( LAW ) and the enforcement of the judgment , but to no avail . The authorities in question replied that it was beyond their competence to interfere with the judicial process .

CARDINAL . DATE , on DATE , the applicant applied to ORG ( the executive of the ORG ) . Explaining that , owing to his lack of means , he could not bear the expenses in advance , the applicant expressed his willingness to pay an enforcement fee after receiving the judgment debt .

CARDINAL . NORP In its reply of CARDINAL DATE , PERSON noted that the debtor ’s whereabouts were unknown . The ORG reiterated that the non - payment of the preliminary expenses constituted “ an impediment to the enforcement of the judgment ” ; provided that the applicant had covered the necessary expenses in advance , the bailiff would identify the debtor ’s assets , seize them and put them up for auction . As to the enforcement fee of PERCENT of the judgment debt , the ORG stated that this could be paid by the applicant after enforcement ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ) .
CARDINAL . As a result of the non - payment of the preliminary expenses , the judgment of DATE still remains unenforced .

CARDINAL . The applicant was to inherit the apartment of his deceased brother , where relatives of his brother ’s wife were dwelling . Before establishing his rights as an heir , the court satisfied the applicant ’s request for interim measures by ordering the appropriate bailiff to attach the impugned apartment and make an inventory of the movable assets inside .

CARDINAL . After being recognised as the heir , the applicant brought a civil action against the relatives , claiming that they had misappropriated household belongings . After a series of remittals , on DATE ORG partly satisfied the applicant ’s claim by ordering the respondents to return some of the belongings thus claimed .

CARDINAL . According to the case file , the judgment of DATE was received by the applicant on DATE ( the receipt form being written in NORP , a language not understood by the applicant ) . However , the applicant contends that he received the judgment on DATE , along with the relevant receipt form in NORP .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed against the judgment , and on DATE he paid GEL CARDINAL ( EUR CARDINAL ) in court fees . On DATE , taking into consideration the receipt form of DATE , the appellate court dismissed the appeal as time - barred . On an unspecified date the court fees were returned to the applicant .
CARDINAL . The applicant applied to different judicial and administrative authorities , requesting an expert report on the authenticity of the receipt form dated DATE , but to no avail .

CARDINAL . In the course of divorce proceedings , the ORG established on DATE that the CARDINAL - room apartment where the applicant and his wife had been residing during their marriage was their common matrimonial property . Following the divorce , the court entitled the applicant ’s former wife to a room in the disputed apartment . The applicant appealed against this decision , complaining , among other issues , that the case had been examined in his absence . On DATE the appellate court , noting that the applicant ’s representative had attended the hearing before ORG , dismissed his appeal . ORG of GPE upheld the appellate court ’s judgment on DATE .
CARDINAL . In the course of the enforcement of the decision of DATE , the applicant ’s aunt was evicted from the room to which the applicant ’s former spouse was entitled .

CARDINAL . NORP In a decision of DATE , ORG recognised the applicant as a victim of political repression and ordered his judicial rehabilitation . By virtue of a decree of the President of GPE dated DATE , rehabilitated citizens of GPE are entitled to certain welfare benefits . The applicant applied to different administrative authorities , claiming those benefits , but to no avail .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW read :
“ Every person has the right to apply to a court for protection of his or her rights and freedoms . ”
“ ORG of GPE shall , ... on the basis of a citizen ’s complaint , examine the compatibility of normative acts with LAW of the LAW . ”
The Second Chapter , consisting of Articles CARDINAL to CARDINAL , lists human rights and freedoms .
CARDINAL . LAW of DATE , as in force at the material time , provides , in so far as relevant :

“ ORG of GPE ( hereinafter ORG ) is the body of constitutional supervision , which shall guarantee the supremacy of LAW , constitutional justice , and the protection of the constitutional rights and freedoms of individuals . ”

“ On the basis of a constitutional complaint or application , the Constitutional Court shall be competent to examine and decide ... upon the issue of the constitutionality of normative acts with respect to LAW of the LAW . ”

“ The declaration of a statute or another normative act as unconstitutional shall not result in the quashing of judicial decisions and judgments already given on the basis of the impugned act . It shall only suspend enforcement proceedings in accordance with procedural legislation . ”
“ The right to lodge a constitutional complaint with ORG in order to challenge the constitutionality of a normative act or the provisions thereof ... shall be vested in :

( a ) NORP nationals , other physical persons residing in GPE and NORP legal entities , if they consider that their rights as envisaged by Chapter II of the LAW have been or might be directly breached ;
( b ) the Public Defender , if the latter considers that there has been a violation of the human rights and freedoms set forth in LAW of the LAW . ”
CARDINAL . LAW of DATE , as in force at the material time , provides , in so far as relevant :
“ A constitutional complaint or application shall be deemed inadmissible if :
( e ) the disputed issue is not governed by LAW . ”
CARDINAL . LAW of DATE ( “ the Enforcement Act ” ) , as in force at the material time , reads , in so far as relevant :
“ Bailiffs at enforcement offices [ of ORG ] shall be responsible for the enforcement of the decisions provided for hereunder . ”
“ The amount of the expenses relating to enforcement shall be calculated by the bailiff , and may be reviewed during the enforcement process . ”
“ Bailiffs are entitled to use funds allocated from the ORG budget ... in order to enforce urgent judgments as listed in LAW ( a ) to ( d ) of LAW ... ”
“ Requests by bailiffs in the course of their duties shall be equally binding on any natural person or legal entity , irrespective of their hierarchical or legal and administrative status .

Bailiffs shall resort to any lawful measures available in order to secure the speedy and effective enforcement of decisions , to explain to parties their rights and responsibilities , and to assist in the protection of their rights and legal interests . ”

“ Bailiffs shall initiate enforcement proceedings upon receipt of the writ of enforcement and a written application from the creditor . Bailiffs are entitled to refuse to enforce a judgment in the event of non - payment by the creditor of the preliminary expenses provided for by LAW . ”
“ Expenses relating to enforcement shall be borne by the debtor . They shall be recovered along with the debt . ”
“ Funds may be claimed to cover :
( a ) NORP payment ... for services necessarily required for unlocking doors or for unlocking storage facilities ;
( b ) costs associated with the storage of seized items ;
( c ) expenses associated with the service of public notices ;
( d ) expenses resulting from the detention of a debtor ;
( e ) expenses associated with an auction .
The Minister of ORG of GPE may provide for other expenses to be paid as well . ”

CARDINAL . Pursuant to Order no . CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Minister of ORG dated DATE , apart from the items listed in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW , the costs resulting from ( a ) bank services , ( b ) searching the debtor ’s property , ( c ) auditing , ( d ) transportation of movable assets and ( e ) telephone and postal services are treated as enforcement - related expenses .

“ Prior to the enactment of LAW , a fee for the payment of judgment debts shall be introduced and its amount set at PERCENT of the judgment debt . The creditor shall pay the fee after receiving the debt ... ”
CARDINAL . LAW has not been enacted to date .
CARDINAL . The Georgian Criminal Code provides , in so far as relevant :

“ The non - enforcement of a binding judgment or other judicial decision , or the obstruction of its execution by the ORG , government or local - government officials or by executives of a corporation or of other organisations [ shall be punished ] ... ”
CARDINAL . The Georgian Code of Civil Procedure provides :
“ Pursuant to a request by a party , the court may deliver the following types of judgment to be immediately enforced in part or in full :
( a ) judgments concerning entitlement to alimony ;
( b ) judgments concerning entitlement to compensation for damage caused by mutilation or other bodily injury or by the death of a carer ;
( c ) judgments concerning an employee ’s entitlement to loss of earnings for DATE ;
( d ) judgments concerning the reinstatement of an unlawfully dismissed person . ”
CARDINAL . A ORG expert ’s opinion of DATE on proposals for amending ORG and LAW contains the following passage :

“ It is to be conceded that decisions by ORG may contain some vagueness as regards their execution . ORG , in order to cope with this problem , might take into consideration the solution in the NORP PERSON on ORG which provides in LAW may state by whom it is to be executed ; in individual instances it may also specify the method of ORG ”
CARDINAL . The Opinion of the Venice Commission on Draft Constitutional Amendments concerning the Reform of the ORG in GPE ( CARDINALnd GPE , GPE , DATE ) includes the following passage :

“ CARDINAL . The existing LAW ( f ) [ of LAW ] already provides for individual access to ORG in the form of a so - called ‘ non - real’ constitutional complaint ( term used in NORP doctrine ) against normative acts . It is welcomed that the draft LAW ( f ) would give this right not only to citizens but to persons in general .

CARDINAL . In addition to this , draft LAW ( f ) would allow ORG to consider the ‘ constitutionality of decisions of courts with regards to fundamental human rights and freedoms set forth in LAW of the LAW on the basis of a claim of an individual or the application by ORG of Georgia’ . The draft thus adds a ‘ real’ constitutional complaint also against individual acts DATE final court decisions .

CARDINAL . This provision represents a substantial increase in the jurisdiction and powers of ORG . ORG is given a power of review over the ordinary courts’ decisions where human rights questions are concerned . The fact that the jurisdiction to review can be exercised on the complaint of a citizen creates a powerful new tool for the enforcement of the human rights and fundamental freedoms guaranteed by LAW . ”
